&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 2&lt;/b&gt; &amp;#150; &lt;b&gt;Endorsement&#13;/ Spokesperson / Consulting Agreements&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company is obligated under&#13;various endorsement, spokesperson and consulting agreements with varying original terms ranging from one to three years. These&#13;endorsers, spokespersons and consultants are generally paid a monthly fee for their services, including promotion and marketing&#13;activities per the agreements. All of these agreements may be terminated by either party upon breach or default in the terms of&#13;the agreements. The Company expensed $232,248 and $71,426 under these agreements in 2012 and 2011, respectively.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 3&lt;/b&gt; &amp;#150; &lt;b&gt;Retirement&#13;Plan&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 4 &amp;#150; Sale of Product&#13;Line&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 5&lt;/b&gt; &amp;#150; &lt;b&gt;Contingencies&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 6 &amp;#150; Litigation&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company is engaged in various&#13;legal actions, claims and proceedings arising in the normal course of business, including claims related to breach of contracts,&#13;product liabilities and intellectual property matters resulting from the Company&amp;#146;s business activities. As with most actions&#13;such as these, an estimation of any possible and/or ultimate liability cannot always be determined. The following summaries highlight&#13;the current status of certain material commercial litigation in which the Company is involved.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Protica, Inc., a former manufacturer&#13;of products for the Company, sued the Predecessor Company for an alleged debt in the approximate amount of $384,000 and also unspecified&#13;damages for an alleged breach of an exclusive manufacturing agreement. The Company filed counterclaims alleging Protica breached&#13;the parties' agreement and the warranties implied therein and fraudulently concealed damage to the product manufactured for it&#13;resulting in an FDA recall of its product and loss of a significant portion of its commercial market. The case was filed February&#13;15, 2011 in the United States District Court, Eastern District of Pennsylvania. The Company sought an unspecified amount of direct&#13;damages, punitive damages, and attorneys' fees. The Company and Protica, Inc. fully and finally settle this matter effective April&#13;1, 2013. The settlement has been included in the Company&amp;#146;s year-end 2012 financial results.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company received a demand&#13;letter, dated February 17, 2012, from the Breeden Law firm, claiming the Company&amp;#146;s sale of its African Mango Super Fruit&amp;#153;&#13;diet product, (the &amp;#147;Mango Product&amp;#148;) violated the California Consumer Legal Remedies Act and certain other provisions&#13;of California State law. This Letter demanded the Company: (i) substantiate its advertising claims with respect to the Mango Product;&#13;(ii) change its advertising with respect to the Mango Product; (iii) recall the Mango Product; (iv) identify all purchasers of&#13;the Mango Product; and (v) establish a fund for the providing for a full refund for all purchasers of the Mango Product. No formal&#13;litigation has been initiated against the Company as of this date. On March 23, 2012, the Company received a letter from Vitamin&#13;World, Inc. (&amp;#147;Vitamin World&amp;#148;) requesting the Company indemnify Vitamin World for similar claims brought against it by&#13;the Breeden Law Firm concerning the Mango Product sold by Vitamin World. The Company&amp;#146;s indemnification obligations to Vitamin&#13;World arise from the standard terms and conditions contained in Vitamin World&amp;#146;s distribution agreements. The Company has&#13;agreed to indemnify Vitamin World in this matter. The Company believes there is a reasonable possibility, as defined by FASB ASC&#13;450-20, of an unfavorable outcome. However, the range of any possible loss cannot be reasonably estimated as of the date of the&#13;financial statements. The Company&amp;#146;s counsel is in communication with the complainant with regard to the requested label changes&#13;and settlement issues.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Arya Tabibnia brought a class&#13;action complaint against the Company which was filed on August 6, 2012 in the United States District Court for the Southern District&#13;of California (the &amp;#147;Tabibnia Action&amp;#148;), claiming the Company&amp;#146;s sale of its hCG Activator natural hCG alternative&#13;(the &amp;#147;Product&amp;#148;) violated the California Consumer Legal Remedies Act and certain other provisions of California state&#13;law. The Company also received letters from GNC, Corp. and Vitamin Shoppe, Inc., demanding the Company indemnify them pursuant&#13;to their respective vendor agreements. The Company is contractually obligated to indemnify both GNC, Corp. and Vitamin Shoppe,&#13;Inc. and will fulfill those responsibilities. The Company believes that there is reasonable possibility, as defined by FASB ASC&#13;450-20, of an unfavorable outcome. However, the range of any possible loss cannot be reasonably estimated as of the date of the&#13;financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Jeffrey Grube brought a class&#13;action lawsuit against three firms, including the Company, based on the defendants' alleged marketing, distribution, or sales&#13;of products purporting to contain human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) or a natural hCG alternative. The case is referred to as&#13;Jeffrey Grube v. GNC, iSatori Technologies LLC, and HCG Platinum, LLC, Case No. 11-1005, filed August 4, 2011 in United States&#13;District Court, for the Western District of Pennsylvania. Grube claims that the defendants engaged in deceptive trade practices&#13;in violation of numerous state consumer protection laws, breached express warranties, and were unjustly enriched. The Company&#13;received a letter from GNC Corp., demanding the Company indemnify GNC Corp. pursuant to a distribution agreement between the Company&#13;and GNC Corp. The Company is contractually obligated to indemnify GNC Corp and will fulfill that responsibility. The action has&#13;been dismissed voluntarily by the plaintiff; the Company believes that the claims represented by this action may ultimately be&#13;included in the claims advanced in the Tabibnia Action, described above. As a result, no other actions are planned by the Company&#13;on this matter. Accordingly, the range of any possible exposure regarding this particular claim cannot be reasonably estimated&#13;as of the date of the financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;D. Tawnsaura brought a class&#13;action complaint against the Company and 56 other retailers/distributors for infringement of a patented ingredient &amp;#147;Citriline&#13;Malate&amp;#148;. This ingredient is utilized by the Company in certain of its product formulations. The court ordered the plaintiffs&#13;to resubmit their complaint and make it legally sufficient, which occurred on October 31, 2012. The Company and many of the other&#13;defendants are contesting the alleged patent position of the plaintiff; accordingly, discovery in this matter has been stayed&#13;pending the resolution of this issue. The Company believes that there is a reasonable possibility, as defined by FASB ASC 450-20,&#13;of an unfavorable outcome. However, the range of any possible loss cannot be reasonably estimated as of the date of the financial&#13;statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 7&lt;/b&gt; &amp;#150; &lt;b&gt;Income&#13;Taxes&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;As noted above, the Predecessor&#13;Company converted from a limited liability company to a corporation on June 1, 2011. For the five months ending May 31, 2011,&#13;the taxable income (or loss) of the Predecessor Company, a limited liability company, was allocated to its sole member. Therefore,&#13;no provision or liability for income taxes has been included in these financial statements for these relevant periods when the&#13;Predecessor Company was in existence. As a result of the June 1, 2011 conversion, on that date the Company recorded a net deferred&#13;tax asset of $274,489, by a credit to income tax expense, for temporary differences between financial reporting and the income&#13;tax basis of the existing assets and liabilities at that date.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;For the year ended December 31&#13;2012, the Company recognized income tax benefit of $737, which reflects the adjustment of the above mentioned net tax asset in&#13;the amount of $67,083, offset by the net tax expense of the year totaling $66,346. For the year ended December 31, 2011, the Company&#13;recognized a net income tax benefit of $225,450.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;At December 31, 2012, management&#13;believes there are no uncertain tax liabilities. The Company recognizes interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions&#13;in income tax (benefit)/expense. No interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions were accrued at December 31, 2012.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company files income tax returns in U.S. federal&#13;jurisdiction and various states. There are currently no federal or state income tax examinations underway for these jurisdictions.&#13;The 2012 tax year remains open to examination by taxing jurisdictions to which the Company is subject.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Serif&gt;0.0%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: #000000 3px double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;-59.8%&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets,&#13;management considers whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will be realized.&#13;The ultimate realization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income during the periods in&#13;which those temporary differences become deductible. Management considers the scheduled reversal of deferred tax liabilities,&#13;projected future taxable income and tax planning strategies in making this assessment. Management believes it is not more-likely-than-not&#13;that the Company will realize the benefits of the net operating losses at December 31, 2012. The Company&amp;#146;s deferred tax&#13;valuation allowance of $11,041,594 reflected below is an increase of $10,972,559 as there was no valuation allowance recorded&#13;as of December 31, 2011.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The components of the deferred&#13;tax assets, net of deferred tax liabilities for each period are:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=width: 100%; margin-top: 0px; font-size: 9pt&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 70%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 14%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 2%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 14%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&lt;font style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: #000000 1px solid; vertical-align: bottom; font-size: 8.5pt; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Serif&gt;252,245&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;At December 31, 2012, the Company&#13;had $28,730,000 of cumulated net operating loss carryforwards before application of Internal Revenue Code 382 limitations for&#13;federal income tax purposes that were available to offset future taxable income through the year 2032.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 8 &amp;#150; Stockholders&amp;#146;&#13;Equity&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;At December 31, 2012, there were&#13;12,622,756 shares of common stock, par value $.01 per share, outstanding for the Company&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Effective February 16, 2012,&#13;the Company issued options to purchase 1,233,129 shares of the Company&amp;#146;s common stock to eight management employees with&#13;an initial exercise price of $0.38 per share and which contain various vesting schedules and expiration dates. Upon completion&#13;of the merger, the total number of options to purchase such shares was reduced to 823,757 and the per share exercise price was&#13;correspondingly adjusted to $0.573 per share in accordance with the terms of the Merger Agreement.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Effective February 16, 2012,&#13;in connection with the $250,000 Convertible Promissory Note dated October 15, 2010 between the Company and James and Kristin Black,&#13;the Company exchanged 493,252 Common Shares of stock for the cancellation of the Note Payable. In accordance with the terms of&#13;the Merger, the total number of shares was reduced to 329,502.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;i&gt;Warrant Grants&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;As of December 31, 2012, there&#13;were common stock warrants outstanding to purchase aggregate shares of common stock pursuant to the warrant grants described below.&#13;On November 1, 2010, the Company issued warrants to purchase 150,000 shares of the common stock of the Company to Transition Partners,&#13;Limited with a an indeterminable exercise price per share in connection with a consulting services agreement. These warrants were&#13;subject to a conditional vesting schedule, in one-third increments. As of December 31, 2010, the first 50,000 of these warrants&#13;were fully vested and were due to expire on November 1, 2013. On June 17, 2011, the second 50,000 of these warrants were fully&#13;vested and due to expire on November 1, 2013. On April 6, 2012 the third 50,000 of these warrants were fully vested and were due&#13;to expire on November 1, 2013. Upon completion of and in accordance with the terms of the Merger, the total number of warrants&#13;to purchase such shares was reduced to 123,563 and the per share exercise price was fixed at $0.57 per share. In addition, the&#13;expiration of the warrants was extended to July 31, 2015.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;On June 17, 2011 the Company&#13;also issued warrants to purchase 50,000 shares of the common stock of the Company to AVIDBank Corporate Finance, a division of&#13;AVIDBank, with an exercise price equal to one-hundredth of a dollar in connection with the $1.0 million revolving line of credit&#13;arrangement (See Note 8, Revolving Lines of Credit and Related Interest). These warrants are fully vested and expire on June 17,&#13;2016. Upon completion of the Merger, the total number of warrants to purchase such shares was reduced to 33,401 and the per share&#13;exercise price remained the same.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;On July 15, 2011 the Company&#13;also issued warrants to purchase 3% of fully diluted shares of the common stock of the Company to Breakwater Structured Growth&#13;Opportunity Fund, L.P., with an imputed exercise price equal to approximately one-hundredth of a dollar in connection with the&#13;$1.025 million subordinated mezzanine loan arrangement (See Note 9, Long Term Indebtedness and Interest). These warrants are fully&#13;vested and expire on June 15, 2016. In accordance with the terms of the Merger, the total number of warrants to purchase such&#13;shares was increased from 328,411 shares to 420,549 and the per share exercise price remained the same.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Included in the aforementioned&#13;Breakwater warrant, was an obligation by the Company to, among other things, honor an irrevocable put right through which the&#13;Company agreed to purchase up to the 3% of fully diluted shares of its common stock underlying the warrant, which expires on July&#13;15, 2016 (See Note 9, Long Term Indebtedness and Interest). Upon completion of the Merger, the irrevocable put right was removed.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;i&gt;Option Grant&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;On September 6, 2012, the Company&#13;entered into a one year investor relations consulting contract with RJ Falkner &amp;#38; Company, Inc (&amp;#147;RJ Falkner&amp;#148;),&#13;which includes a grant to R. Jerry Falkner, the owner of RJ Falkner, as an individual, a five year option to purchase 125,000&#13;of share of common stock and an exercise price of $2.25 per share. These options were subject to a conditional vesting schedule,&#13;in one-fourth increments. The first installment vested and became exercisable upon execution of the consulting contract on September&#13;6, 2012. The second installment upon the publication of the first &amp;#147;Research Profile&amp;#148; report, which was completed November&#13;30, 2012, The third and fourth installments will vest at 90 and 180 days following the publication of the aforementioned report.&#13;As of December 31, 2012, the two of the four increments were fully vested for a total of 62,500 shares are due to expire on September&#13;5, 2017.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Effective September 28, 2012,&#13;the Company issued options to purchase 54,479 shares of the Company&amp;#146;s common stock to ten employees with an exercise price&#13;of $2.25 per share and which contain three year vesting schedules of 1/3 each year through September 2015. These options are due&#13;to expire on September 27, 2022.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Effective November 30, 2012,&#13;the Company issued options to purchase 100,000 shares of the Company&amp;#146;s common stock to two consultants with an exercise&#13;price of $2.50 per share and were subject to a three year vesting schedule, in one-third increments. The first vesting period&#13;begins on November 30, 2013. These options are due to expire on November 30, 2022.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;In developing a fair value for&#13;the Avid warrant obligation at December 31, 2012, the Company used a current stock value of $2.28 per share, which represents&#13;a discount of 24% from the quoted stock price. This reduction was based on the application of a Discount for Lack of Marketability.&#13;The Company, in developing a fair value for the Breakwater warrant obligation at December 31, 2012, used a current stock value&#13;of $1.50 per share, which represents a discount of 50% from the quoted stock price. This reduction was based on the application&#13;of a Discount for Lack of Liquidity. Other assumptions used in the above valuations include (a) risk-free interest rate of 0.36%&#13;based on duration, (b) weighted average expected terms ranging from 3.5 to 3.58 years; (c) weighted average expected stock volatility&#13;of 45.94 % and (e) expected dividends of 0%.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The values of the other various&#13;warrants and options have been measured utilizing the Black-Scholes model as of December 31, 2012. The assumptions used in this&#13;valuation included: (a) risk-free interest rate ranging from 0.36-1.78% based on duration, (c) weighted average expected terms&#13;ranging from 2.58 years to 10 years; (d) weighted average expected stock volatility ranging from 43.84-48.97 % and (e) expected&#13;dividends of 0%. These valuations resulted in an annual 2012 expense of $858,398 included in the Statement of Operations.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;i&gt;February&#13;2012 Management Options&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Effective February 16, 2012,&#13;the Company issued options to purchase 1,233,129 shares of the Company stock to eight management employees, having an initial&#13;exercise price of $0.38, and which contain various vesting schedules and expiration dates. Upon completion of the merger, the&#13;total number of options to purchase such shares was reduced to 823,757 and the per share exercise price was correspondingly adjusted&#13;to $0.573 per share in accordance with the terms of the Merger Agreement&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company applied fair value&#13;accounting for all share based payments awards. The fair value of each option granted is estimated on the date of grant using&#13;the Black-Scholes option-pricing model, for a total valuation of $61,495, which was expensed in full on the date of the grant.&#13;The Black-Scholes assumptions used when the options were issued in the year ended December 31, 2012 are as follows:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=margin-top: 0px; font-size: 10pt; width: 100%&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 88%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Serif&gt;Outstanding options held by related parties &amp;#150; 2012&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: #000000 3px double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;Exercisable options held by related parties &amp;#150; 2012&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: #000000 3px double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;623,350&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;i&gt;2012 Performance Incentive&#13;Plan&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;On September 27, 2012, the Company's&#13;board of directors approved the 2012 Performance Incentive Plan (the Plan&amp;#148;). The Plan allows the Company to promote the&#13;success of the Corporation and to increase stockholder value by providing an additional means through the grant of awards to attract,&#13;motivate, retain and reward selected employees and other eligible persons. Any stock option granted in the form of an incentive&#13;stock option will be intended to comply with the&lt;font style=color: #00007f&gt; &lt;/font&gt;requirements of Section 422 of the Code.&#13;Only stock options granted to employees qualify for incentive stock option treatment. A stock option may be exercised in whole&#13;or in installments, which may be cumulative. Shares of common stock purchased upon the exercise of a stock option must be paid&#13;for in full at the time of the exercise in cash or such other consideration determined by the compensation committee. Payment&#13;may include tendering shares of common stock or surrendering of a stock award, or a combination of methods.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Plan is administered by the&#13;Plan Administrator, being the Board or one or more committees appointed by the Board or another committee (within its delegated&#13;authority) to administer all or certain aspects of this Plan. The Administrator has full and exclusive power within the limitations&#13;set forth in the Plan to make all decisions and determinations regarding the selection of participants and the granting of awards;&#13;establishing the terms and conditions relating to each award; adopting rules, regulations and guidelines; and interpreting the&#13;Plan.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;On September 28, 2012, the Company&#13;issued options to purchase 54,519 shares of the Company stock to ten employees, having an exercise price of $2.25, and which contain&#13;three year vesting schedules of 1/3 each year through September 2015. These options are due to expire on September 27, 2022.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company applied fair value&#13;accounting for all share based payments awards. The fair value of each option granted is estimated on the date of grant using&#13;the Black-Scholes option-pricing model, for a total valuation of $51,978, which will be expensed over the three year vesting period.&#13;The expense realized for the year ending December 31, 2012 was $1,999. The Black-Scholes assumptions used when the options were&#13;issued in the year ended December 31, 2012 are as follows:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=width: 100%; margin-top: 0px; font-size: 9pt&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 75%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Times

 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&lt;i&gt;Contractor&#13;Options&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;During the year ended December&#13;31, 2012, the Company issued options to purchase 225,000 shares of the Company stock to outside contractors, having an exercise&#13;price ranging between $2.25 and $2.50, and which contain various vesting schedules and expiration dates.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company applied fair value&#13;accounting for all share based payments awards. The fair value of each option granted is estimated on the date of grant using&#13;the Black-Scholes option-pricing model, for a total valuation of $199,014, which was expensed in full on the date of the grant.&#13;The Black-Scholes assumptions used when the options were issued in the year ended December 31, 2012 are as follows:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=width: 100%; margin-top: 0px; font-size: 9pt&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 84%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Times

 Times

 Times

 Serif&gt;4.75&#13;    years&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company had previously valued&#13;the AVIDBank and Breakwater warrants using a model that did not include the quoted stock price as an input, and has determined&#13;that the model described above should have been used in valuing these warrants for the quarters ended June 30, 2012 and September&#13;30, 2012. The following summarizes the effects of this change.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=width: 100%; margin-top: 0px; font-size: 9pt&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 49%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Times

 Times

 Serif&gt;(0.07)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company assumed the 1,069,587&#13;outstanding warrants to purchase shares of Common Stock which were issued by Integrated in fiscal years 2009 and before. Of these,&#13;17,230 expired on July 29, 2012 and the remainders expire on May 31, 2014.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 9 &amp;#150; CONVERTIBLE&#13;PREFERRED STOCK&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;In connection with the Merger,&#13;the Company assumed into its capital structure the convertible stock originally issued by Integrated. Accordingly, at December&#13;31, 2012, the Company&amp;#146;s convertible preferred stock, $0.01 par value per share, consisted of the following:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=width: 100%; margin-top: 0px; font-size: 10pt&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 50%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 14%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 17%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 15%&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Liquidation&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;        &lt;p style=font-size: 8.5pt; text-align: center; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 8pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Preference&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #f3f3f3&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=font-size: 9pt&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Serif&gt;450,000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Series A $20 Convertible Preferred&#13;Stock. At December 31, 2012, the Company had 9,500 shares of its Series A $20 Convertible Preferred Stock (the &amp;#147;Series A&#13;Preferred&amp;#148;) outstanding. Holders of the Series A Preferred are not entitled to receive any dividends, and have no voting&#13;rights unless otherwise required pursuant to Delaware law. Each share of the Series A Preferred may, at the option of the Company,&#13;be converted into the equivalent of one-fifth (1/5th) of a share of common stock at any time after (i) the closing bid price of&#13;the common stock is at least $2.00 for at least 20 trading days during any 30 consecutive trading day period, and (ii) the shares&#13;of common stock to be received on conversion have been registered or otherwise qualified for sale under applicable securities&#13;laws. The holders of the Series A Preferred have the right to convert each share into the equivalent of one-fifth (1/5th) of a&#13;share of common stock at any time. Upon any liquidation, dissolution, or winding up of the Company, the holders of the Series&#13;A Preferred are entitled to receive $20 per share before the holders of common stock are entitled to receive any distribution.&#13;In the event the Company enters into any consolidation, merger or other transaction in which the shares of Common Stock are exchanged&#13;for or changed into other stock or other securities, each share of Series A Preferred will at the same time be similarly exchanged&#13;or changed into such consideration as is equal to four times the amount of consideration to be received for each share of common&#13;stock.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Series D $20 Convertible Preferred&#13;Stock. At December 31, 2012 the Company had 13,000 shares of its Series D $20 Convertible Preferred Stock (the &amp;#147;Series D&#13;Preferred&amp;#148;) outstanding. Holders of the Series D Preferred are entitled to receive, out of funds of the Company legally available,&#13;dividends at the annual rate of $1.80 per annum per share.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Serif&gt;260,000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #f3f3f3&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman

 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; text-indent: -2px; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note&#13;10 - Revolving Line of Credit and Related Interest&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;On June 17, 2012, the Company&#13;extended a $1.0 million revolving line of credit with a lender, with interest due monthly at the rate equal to prime plus 1.25%&#13;with a floor of 7.0% for one month, which was originally entered into on June 17, 2011. The line of credit was collateralized&#13;by the Company&amp;#146;s accounts receivable, inventory, contract rights and general intangibles. The Company&amp;#146;s line of credit&#13;agreement contains certain restrictive covenants including the prohibition of the payment of distributions to members or stockholders&#13;other than for the payment of income taxes and certain affirmative covenants including maintenance of certain financial ratios&#13;related to its financial performance as defined in the line of credit agreement. For the quarter ended December 31, 2011, the&#13;Company failed to meet its Minimum Net Income Covenant. A waiver from the lender was obtained. At December 31, 2011 advances of&#13;$785,044 were outstanding under the credit agreement. The lender bank had not set a requirement for the Minimum Net Income Covenant&#13;for 1st or 2nd quarter. This revolving line of credit has subsequently been paid in full on July 16, 2012 with proceeds from a&#13;new credit agreement and all liens released.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company entered into a&#13;new Credit Agreement with Colorado Business Bank West of Denver, Colorado (the &amp;#147;New Credit Agreement&amp;#148;) on July 16,&#13;2012, and in connection with the entrance into the New Credit Agreement, terminated its commitments under its existing credit&#13;agreement with Avidbank Corporate Finance, a division of AvidBank. Borrowings under the New Credit Agreement will be used to&#13;provide ongoing working capital and for other general corporate purposes of the Company and its subsidiaries. For the year&#13;ended December 31, 2012, the Company failed to meet its Minimum Tagible Net Equity Covenant for the month of December, 2012.&#13;The Company is currently in communications with the bank to obtain a waiver but it is uncertain as to whether the Company&#13;will be able to obtain the waiver. The loan is currently classified as a current liability.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; text-indent: -2px; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note&#13;11 - Long-Term Indebtedness and Interest&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;In October, 2010, the Company&#13;entered into a $250,000 long-term debt arrangement (the &amp;#147;Note&amp;#148;) with an unrelated private investor, with interest due&#13;monthly at the rate equal to 10%. The principal amount of the Note was required by the Predecessor Company to be repaid in full&#13;on its first anniversary. However, at that time, if the Predecessor Company had not entered into a satisfactory subsequent financing&#13;arrangement, in the sole discretion of the investor, the $250,000 Note could be immediately called and would be due and payable.&#13;The holder of the Note had the option to then either convert the Note into a three-year term loan or convert the Note into shares&#13;of common stock in the Predecessor Company. The holder of the Note had 15 months from the first anniversary of the making of the&#13;Note to make this decision, that is, until December 31, 2012. Subsequently, in February, 2012, the Note holder agreed that all&#13;previous new financing contingencies had been met and consented to convert the Note into 493,252 shares of common stock of the&#13;Company in complete and total satisfaction of the Note. In accordance with the terms of the Merger, the total number of shares&#13;was reduced to 329,502.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 12 &amp;#150; Fair Value&#13;Measurements and Disclosures&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company follows ASC 820,&#13;Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures, which defines fair value, establishes a framework for using fair value to measure assets&#13;and liabilities, and expands disclosures about fair value measurements. The statement establishes a hierarchy for inputs used&#13;in measuring fair value that maximizes the use of observable inputs and minimizes the use of unobservable inputs by requiring&#13;that the most observable inputs be used when available. Observable inputs are inputs that market participants would use in pricing&#13;the asset or liability developed based on market data obtained from sources independent of the Company. Unobservable inputs are&#13;inputs that reflect the Company&amp;#146;s assumptions of what market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability developed&#13;based on the best information available in the circumstances. The hierarchy is broken down into three levels based on the reliability&#13;of the inputs as follows:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Level 1: Quoted prices are available&#13;in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Level 2: Quoted prices in active&#13;markets for similar assets and liabilities that are observable for the asset or liability; or&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Level 3: Unobservable pricing&#13;inputs that are generally less observable from objective sources, such as discounted cash flow models or valuations.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;ASC 820 requires financial assets&#13;and liabilities to be classified based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement. The Company&amp;#146;s&#13;assessment of the significance of a particular input to the fair value measurement requires judgment, and may affect the valuation&#13;of the fair value of assets and liabilities and their placement within the fair value hierarchy levels.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;For the purposes of marketable securities where there&#13;is an active market, the Company uses the quoted prices available for the identical asset or liability. As of December 31, 2012,&#13;the Company had $965,886 in a highly liquid investment account and $29,338 assets held for sale valued using the Level 1 mark-to-market&#13;approach.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The inputs used in the fair value measurements categorized&#13;within Level 3 include the stock price at the valuation date, the exercise price of the warrant, the expected period of time the&#13;warrant will be outstanding, the annual volatility of the underlying stock price, the annual yield rate of quarterly dividends,&#13;and the risk free rate of interest relevant to the expected time period the warrant will be outstanding.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The following table&#13;represents the Company&amp;#146;s warrant derivative liabilities that were accounted for at fair value on a recurring&#13;basis by level within the fair value hierarchy:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=margin-top: 0px; font-size: 9pt; width: 100%&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=font-size: 1pt&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 13 &amp;#150; Supplemental&#13;Cash Flow Information&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;The Company remitted cash payments&#13;for federal and state income taxes of $71,000 for the period from June 1, 2011 through December 31, 2011. In addition, the Company&#13;remitted cash payments for interest expense related to outstanding debt of $171,853 and $57,259 for the years ended December 31,&#13;2011 and 2010.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0pt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 14 &amp;#150; Subsequent&#13;Events&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;As mentioned in Note 1, under&#13;the Lease section, the Company signed an amendment to its facility lease as of November 1, 2012, which extends its original lease&#13;of 7,120 square feet for a term of four years and three months. This lease also includes the expansion of the facility for an&#13;additional 2,924 square feet, which will be assumed upon the satisfactory completion of the build-out per the Company, which was&#13;complete in the first quarter of 2013.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;As mentioned in Note 1, under&#13;the Notes Receivable section, the Company novated a note receivable which was entered into in December, 2010, for the sale of&#13;a dormant product line of vitamins, A new promissory note was issued to reflect a modification in the payment terms, which includes&#13;no interest. The total amount to be repaid is the open principal amount of $117,543 at December 31, 2012, and is due to be repaid&#13;on or before May 1, 2017. An allowance in the amount of $25,978 has been recorded against the receivable balance.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&lt;b&gt;Earnings (Loss) Per Share&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;Net earnings (loss) per share&#13;is computed by dividing net income (loss) less preferred dividends for the period by the weighted average number of common stock&#13;outstanding during each period. Diluted earnings (loss) per share is computed by dividing net income (loss) less preferred dividends&#13;for the period by the weighted average number of common stock, common stock equivalents and potentially dilutive securities outstanding&#13;during each period.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=text-align: justify; margin: 0&gt;&lt;font style=font: 10pt Times New Roman
 Times

 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15

This reference is included to help users transition from the previous accounting hierarchy and will be removed from future versions of this taxonomy.
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            

 in 'PnYnMnDTnHnMnS' format
 for example
 'P1Y5M13D' represents the reported fact of one year
 five months
 and thirteen days.

Endorsement
/ Spokesperson / Consulting Agreements

The Company is obligated under
various endorsement
 spokesperson and consulting agreements with varying original terms ranging from one to three years. These
endorsers
 spokespersons and consultants are generally paid a monthly fee for their services
 including promotion and marketing
activities per the agreements. All of these agreements may be terminated by either party upon breach or default in the terms of
the agreements. The Company expensed $232
248 and $71
426 under these agreements in 2012 and 2011
 respectively.

Future payments of the above
mentioned contracts will run through 2013
 for a total expense of $110
333.

 which is a bank's commitment to make loans up to a specific amount. Examples of items that might be included in the application of this element may consist of letters of credit
 standby letters of credit
 and revolving credit arrangements
 under which borrowings can be made up to a maximum amount as of any point in time conditional on satisfaction of specified terms before
 as of and after the date of drawdowns on the line. Includes short-term obligations that would normally be classified as current liabilities but for which (a) postbalance sheet date issuance of a long term obligation to refinance the short term obligation on a long term basis
 or (b) the enterprise has entered into a financing agreement that clearly permits the enterprise to refinance the short-term obligation on a long term basis and the following conditions are met (1) the agreement does not expire within 1 year and is not cancelable by the lender except for violation of an objectively determinable provision
 (2) no violation exists at the BS date
 and (3) the lender has entered into the financing agreement is expected to be financially capable of honoring the agreement.

var moreDialog = null;
var Show = {
    Default:'raw'
    more:function( obj ){
        var bClosed = false;
        if( moreDialog != null )
        {
			try
			{
				bClosed = moreDialog.closed;
			}
			catch(e)
			{
				//Per article at http://support.microsoft.com/kb/244375 there is a problem with the WebBrowser control
				// that somtimes causes it to throw when checking the closed property on a child window that has been
				//closed.  So if the exception occurs we assume the window is closed and move on from there.
				bClosed = true;
			}
			if( !bClosed ){
				moreDialog.close();
			}
        }
        obj = obj.parentNode.getElementsByTagName( 'pre' )[0];
		var hasHtmlTag = false;
		var objHtml = '';
		var raw = '';
		//Check for raw HTML
		var nodes = obj.getElementsByTagName( '*' );
		if( nodes.length ){
			objHtml = obj.innerHTML;
		}else{
			if( obj.innerText ){
				raw = obj.innerText;
			}else{
				raw = obj.textContent;
			}

			if( matches && matches.length ){
				objHtml = raw;
				//If there is an html node it will be 1st or 2nd
				//   but we can check a little further.
				var n = Math.min( 5
 matches.length );

					var el = matches[ i ].toString().toLowerCase();

						hasHtmlTag = true;
						break;
					}
				}
			}
		}
        if( objHtml.length ){
			var html = '';
			if( hasHtmlTag ){
				html = objHtml;
			}else{


'+

					\n+'    body {'+
					\n+'    }'+
					\n+'    table {'+
					\n+'    }'+



						objHtml +


			}
			moreDialog = window.open(
More
width=700,height=650,status=0,resizable=yes,menubar=no,toolbar=no,scrollbars=yes);
			moreDialog.document.write( html );
			moreDialog.document.close();
			if( !hasHtmlTag ){
				moreDialog.document.body.style.margin = '0.5em';
			}
        }
        else
        {
			//default view logic
			var lines = raw.split( \n );
			var longest = 0;


					longest = Math.max( longest
 lines[p].length );
				}
			}
			//Decide on the default view

			//Build formatted view

			var formatted = '';

				if( text.length == 1 ){

;
				}else{

\n;
					}
				}
			}else{
';
			}


'+

				\n+'    body {'+
				\n+'       background-color: #f0f9ee;'+
				\n+'       font-family: Arial
 san-serif; font-size: 0.8em;'+
				\n+'    }'+
				\n+'    table {'+
				\n+'       font-size: 1em;'+
				\n+'    }'+




				\n+'    
				\n+'        
'+


				\n+'    
				\n+'        
'+


				\n+'    
				\n+'        
'+





			moreDialog = window.open(
More
width=700,height=650,status=0,resizable=yes,menubar=no,toolbar=no,scrollbars=yes);
			moreDialog.document.write(html);
			moreDialog.document.close();
			this.toggle( moreDialog );
        }
		moreDialog.document.title = 'Report Preview Details';
    }
    toggle:function( win
 domLink ){
        var domId = this.Default;
        var doc = win.document;
        var domEl = doc.getElementById( domId );
        domEl.style.display = 'block';
        this.Default = domId == 'raw' ? 'formatted' : 'raw';
        if( domLink ){
            domLink.innerHTML = this.Default == 'raw' ? 'with Text Wrapped' : 'as Filed';
        }
        var domElOpposite = doc.getElementById( this.Default );
        domElOpposite.style.display = 'none';
    }
	LastAR : null
	showAR : function ( link
 id
 win ){
		if( Show.LastAR ){
			Show.hideAR();
		}
		var ref = link;
		do {
			ref = ref.nextSibling;
		} while (ref && ref.nodeName != 'TABLE');
		if (!ref || ref.nodeName != 'TABLE') {
			var tmp = win ?
				win.document.getElementById(id) :
				document.getElementById(id);
			if( tmp ){
				ref = tmp.cloneNode(true);
				ref.id = '';
				link.parentNode.appendChild(ref);
			}
		}
		if( ref ){
			ref.style.display = 'block';
			Show.LastAR = ref;
		}
	}
	toggleNext : function( link ){
		var ref = link;
		do{
			ref = ref.nextSibling;
		}while( ref.nodeName != 'DIV' );
		if( ref.style &&
			ref.style.display &&
			ref.style.display == 'none' ){
			ref.style.display = 'block';
			if( link.textContent ){
				link.textContent = link.textContent.replace( '+'
 '-' );
			}else{
				link.innerText = link.innerText.replace( '+'
 '-' );
			}
		}else{
			ref.style.display = 'none';
			if( link.textContent ){
				link.textContent = link.textContent.replace( '-'
 '+' );
			}else{
				link.innerText = link.innerText.replace( '-'
 '+' );
			}
		}
	}
	hideAR : function(){
		Show.LastAR.style.display = 'none';
	}
}











    
  
      

          

        

      






        
        


        
        
Note 1 &#150; Summary of
Significant Accounting Policies



iSatori Technologies
 LLC (the
&#147;Predecessor Company&#148;) was formed under the laws of the State of Colorado on June 14
 2004. On June 1
 2011
 LS7 Products
LLC (d/b/a iSatori Global Technologies
 LLC)
 a Colorado limited liability company and wholly owned subsidiary of the Predecessor
Company (&#147;LS7&#148;)
 Eat-Smart
 LLC a Colorado limited liability company and wholly owned subsidiary of the Predecessor
Company (&#147;Eat-Smart&#148;)
 and Energize Solutions
 LLC
 a Colorado limited liability company and wholly owned subsidiary
of the Predecessor Company (&#147;Energize&#148;)
 were merged with and into the Predecessor Company and Right Lane Publishing
Inc.
 a Colorado subchapter S corporation and wholly owned subsidiary of the Predecessor Company (&#147;Right Lane&#148;)
 was
distributed to Stephen Adele Enterprises
 Inc.
 the Predecessor Company&#146;s sole shareholder (collectively
 the &#147;Reorganizations&#148;).
On June 1
 2011
 after consummation of the Reorganizations
 the Predecessor Company converted to a corporation pursuant to the
laws of the State of Colorado changing its name to iSatori Technologies
 Inc. ( &#147;iSatori Technologies&#148;).

On April 5
 2012
 iSatori Acquisition
Corp. (&#147;Merger Sub&#148;)
 a Delaware corporation and wholly-owned subsidiary of Integrated Security Systems
 Inc (&#147;Integrated&#148;)
consummated a merger (the &#147;Merger&#148;) with iSatori Technologies
 pursuant to a Merger Agreement
 dated as of February
17
 2012
 by and among Integrated
 Merger Sub and iSatori Technologies (the &#147;Merger Agreement&#148;). Pursuant to the Merger
Agreement
 iSatori Technologies was merged with and into Merger Sub with iSatori Technologies surviving as a wholly-owned subsidiary
of Integrated.

Upon completion of the Merger
the holders of iSatori Technologies&#146; common stock
 and holders of equity instruments convertible into shares of iSatori Technologies&#146;
common stock
 received an aggregate of approximately 8
410
973
shares of Integrated common stock.

On June 29
 2012
 Integrated
completed a &#147;short form&#148; merger under &#167;253 of the Delaware General Corporation Law pursuant to which iSatori Technologies
was merged with and into Integrated with Integrated continuing as the surviving corporation. In connection with the merger
 Integrated
changed its name to iSatori
 Inc. The trading symbol of the Company on OTCBB is &#147;IFIT&#148;.

Prior to the Merger
 Integrated
was a company with virtually no operations. The Merger was accounted for as the equivalent to the issuance of stock by iSatori
Technologies for the net monetary assets of Integrated. The accompanying financial statements therefore include the consolidated
results of operations of iSatori Technologies and Integrated for periods subsequent to the Merger
 and iSatori Technologies only
for periods prior to the Merger. References to the financial operations of iSatori Technologies and the Predecessor Company are
noted for the respective reporting periods as noted above. Unless otherwise specifically indicated
 references to the &#147;Company&#148;
(without further qualification) necessarily include iSatori Technologies
 the Predecessor Company
 Integrated and iSatori
 Inc.
for all applicable accounting periods. Since there was no change in the ownership of the business in connection with the Reorganizations
the assets and the liabilities of the Predecessor Company have been recorded on iSatori Technologies&#146; financial statements
at the same amounts at which they were reported on the financial statements of the Predecessor Company. All transactions between
divisions and/or wholly owned subsidiaries of iSatori Technologies or the Predecessor Company have been eliminated in the financial
statements. In addition
 per the operating agreement of the Predecessor Company
 no member was to have been liable for the debts
liabilities or obligations of the Predecessor Company.

The Company is engaged in researching
designing
 developing
 contracting for the manufacture
 marketing
 selling and distributing of various nutritional and dietary
supplement products for the general nutrition market. The &#147;general nutrition market&#148; may include such activities as
body-building
 physique enhancement (increase of lean body mass and decrease in fat mass) and enhanced athletic performance through
increased strength and/or endurance and proper nutrition.

The Company does engage from
time to time in funding of clinical studies with the objective of discovering and/or validating claims of new
 efficacious products
for the Company&#146;s relevant market as well as providing necessary and appropriate substantiation for any claims which the
Company may use in its marketing and advertising. The Company markets products which are under its control and which are in some
way proprietary to the Company. Some of the Company&#146;s products are the subject of trademarks owned by the Company.

The accompanying consolidated
financial statements include the accounts of the Company and the Predecessor Company: LS7; Right Lane; Eat-Smart; Energize; and
Integrated for the respective reporting periods described above.



The accompanying consolidated financial Statements
have been prepared on an accrual basis of accounting in accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles in the United
States (&#147;GAAP&#148;). The accompanying consolidated financial statements present the financial position and results of operations
of the Company and include the amounts of the Company as well as the Predecessor Company and all wholly owned subsidiaries. Accordingly
all significant intercompany transactions have been eliminated.



The Company considers all highly
liquid debt instruments purchased with an original maturity of three months or less to be cash equivalents. Accordingly
 cash
and cash equivalents consist of petty cash
 checking accounts and money market funds.

As of December 31
 2012
 the
Company invested approximately$966 thousand with Horter Financial Group which
 acted as investment advisor with and into the Alpha/Pimco
Bonds Plus Total Return Fund. Pimco Corporation is one of the largest bond managers in the world. The Company utilized this Alpha/Pimco
Bonds Plus strategy as a way to create a unique solution to a conservative investor&#146;s dilemma: how to safely invest for income
while increasing the asset base of the money invested at a rate greater than inflation on an after-tax basis.

The underlying
security matures in three years. However
 the Company has access and can liquidate the underlying security on 72-hours&#146;
notice. Thus
 it has  been classified as a current asset. The investment strategy involves an
investment in three separate &#147;power periods&#148;
 late October
 late November and late December of each
year.

The Company invested $960
thousand in this fund. As of December 31
 2012
 the Company realized a net asset value gain of approximately $6 thousand. The
total portfolio of the Company had a stated value therefore of $965
886.

At December 31
 2012 and December
31
 2011
 the financial instruments of the Company and the Predecessor Company consisted principally of cash and cash equivalents
investments
 receivables
 accounts payable
 certain accrued liabilities and long-term debt. The carrying amount of cash and cash
equivalents
 receivables
 accounts payable and accrued liabilities approximates their fair value because of the short maturity
of these instruments. The actual and estimated fair values
 respectively
 of the Company&#146;s financial instruments are as follows:

Trade
receivables are uncollateralized customer obligations due under normal trade terms requiring payment generally within 10-60
days from the invoice date. Accounts are considered delinquent when outstanding for more than 7 days past due date. The
Company does not have a policy of accruing interest on past due accounts. Payments on trade receivables are applied as
instructed per the customer
 or to the earliest unpaid invoices. The allowance for doubtful accounts represents an estimate
considered uncollectible and is determined based on management&#146;s historical collection experience
 adverse situations
that may affect the customer&#146;s ability to repay
 and prevailing economic conditions. Specific accounts deemed
uncollectible are written off periodically with subsequent receipts on previously written off accounts credited to bad debt
expense. The allowance for doubtful accounts is $0 for the years ended December 31
 2012 and 2011
 respectively. Receivables
at each of the below respective periods consisted of the following:

for customer returns in the amount of $68
548 at December 31
 2012 and $50
511 at December 31
 2011 in accrued expenses.

dietary supplements are stated at lower of cost or market on a first-in
 first-out (FIFO) basis as noted below:
